src_text: Adeusa nhwehwɛmufoɔ a wɔfiri Princeton University a ɛwɔ Amɛrika ne Uppsala University a ɛwɔ Sweden kaa sɛ saa nnomaa foforɔ pueeɛ bɛyɛ mfeɛ kakra akyi, mmom wɔgye di sɛ saa nsusuiɛ no akyɛ kakra deɛ, ɛnam mmoawa Darwin finch, Geospiza fortes, aboawa cactus finch a wabɛfra mu ne Geospiza conirostris awoɔ nnidisoɔ.
ref_text: Researchers from Princeton University in the United States and Uppsala University in Sweden reported the new species evolved in just two generations, though this process had been believed to take much longer, due to breeding between an endemic Darwin finch, Geospiza fortes, and the immigrant cactus finch, Geospiza conirostris.
hyp_text: Researchers from Princeton University in America and Uppsala University in Sweden have discovered that these two species of finches, the large cactus finch, Geospiza conirostris, and the sharp-beaked finch, Geospiza fortis, evolved differently over a short period of time, due to the variation in the beak shape of the Darwin finch.

src_text: Ahinime 6, 1789 mu no, mmaa a wɔdi dwa bebree bi hyԑԑ King Louis XVI a na wɔsuro no, Queen Marie Antoinette wɔn mma nketewa mmienu (Marie Therese a wadi mfeԑ du-baako ԑne Louis-Charles a wadi mfeԑ nnan) ԑne Ɔhene no nuabaa, Madam Elizabeth maa wɔsane firi Versailles kɔɔ Paris.
ref_text: The terrified King Louis XVI, Queen Marie Antoinette their two young children (11 year old Marie Therese and four year old Louis-Charles) and the King's sister, Madam Elizabeth, on the 6th October 1789 were forced back to Paris from Versailles by a mob of market women.

ref_text: Such children are called "feral" or wild. Some feral children have been confined by people (usually their own parents); in some cases this child abandonment was due to the parents' rejection of a child's severe intellectual or physical impairment.
hyp_text: Some people call this 'feral' or wild. Some people (especially their parents) consider these 'feral children' as having grown up without proper upbringing; that is, they have grown up without the care and protection of their parents in their early years or have been neglected, so they have become that way.
